message: I have a question? Why Internet Explorer identifies itself as a Mozilla browser in the User-Agent String ??????

data.message: howa keda :)
You should check the last browser name in the string check this http://whatsmyuseragent.com/ or this http://www.useragentstring.com/
my problem is that i'm blocking IE7 Users but most of the sites that generate thumbnails use IE7 engine installed on Windows Server 2003.

so I'm thinking to open it to windows server 2003 only and block the rest of the IE7 Users. home kea keda bahayem le2enohom ma3amloosh updates newga3 dema3'na 2e7na ba2a 3alashan wa7ed 3'aby? :D katkom el 2araf maleeto el balad :D
looooooooooll shaklak maf2o3 awy
by7okaha b3eed 3annak :D
I don't recommend banning IE that way, I would just show an annoying pop-up that tells the user to upgrade
we clear all the website markup and show them a disgusting message. the reason behind this is that we are using technologies that's not supported in IE. not our fault is the fault of Microsoft
I know, but think about crawlers like Search Engines (for SEO) and that thumbnail/snippets generators, URL shorteners..etc, you can't handle all of them

Actually most desktop browsers identify themselves as Mozilla (one of the first internet browsers), then you'll find that the rest of the user agent string identifies it as MSIE. Just search for MSIE in user agent string.

my issue is that we block IE < 9 users but the thumbnail generator websites are getting blocked as well. after doing a small research I found out that they are using Windows Server 2003 64Bit so i enabled it. and issue Fixed :)
Moutaz Shams this won't affect SEO at all as this is all done with Javascript and all the bots disable javascript because they only care for contents ;)
I thought you clear HTML server-side

nop client side :) but i'm working on something good now that might be interesting for heavy sites. i will be loading every section on the page in ajax that google can read https://developers.google.com/webmasters/ajax-crawling/
Good luck dude
What are thumbnail generating sites?
the sites that you give it a url and it generate a thumbnail (Screenshot) of the given URL
How do you know *all* of them run on Windows Server 2003? What is the value of these sites in the first place?

All browsers do it BTW, including Chrome.
Read details here:
http://www.quora.com/User-Agents/Why-do-non-Mozilla-browsers-include-Mozilla-in-their-user-agent-strings
Mozilla doesn't refer to the Mozilla corporation in this context, as explained in the answer.
To check what different browsers on different OSes report as their user agent string, check http://www.useragentstring.com/pages/useragentstring.php
